Trichoplax adhaerens is a simple, multicellular marine organism that belongs to the phylum Placozoa. It is considered one of the most primitive and morphologically simplest known metazoans, or animals with true tissues.

Trichoplax adhaerens is a small, flat, disc-shaped creature, typically less than 1 millimeter in diameter. It has a simple body plan, consisting of only a few different cell types arranged in two epithelial layers. The upper layer is made up of ciliated cells, while the lower layer contains digestive and gland cells.

Despite its simplicity, Trichoplax adhaerens exhibits remarkable capabilities, such as the ability to move, feed, and reproduce asexually through binary fission. It is found in warm, shallow marine environments around the world, often clinging to rocks, algae, or other surfaces.

Scientifically, Trichoplax adhaerens is of great interest because it provides insights into the early evolution of multicellular life and the development of complex animal body plans. Its study has contributed to our understanding of the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying the transition from unicellular to multicellular organisms.
